title: Kyle Edmund loses British No. 1 ranking after Shanghai Masters defeat
text:
Kyle Edmund suffered another defeat (Picture: Getty Images)

Kyle Edmund will drop out of the top-50 of the ATP rankings next week and will no longer be British No. 1 following an early exit at the Shanghai Masters.

Edmund, 24, saw his losing streak extended to six matches by France’s Jeremy Chardy on Monday in a 6-4 7-6 (7-3) defeat in an hour and 39 minutes as his miserable season continues.

Defending quarter-finals points after a good run at the Masters 1000 event a year ago, Edmund will now surrender his title as Britain’s best male tennis player, with Dan Evans in the driving seat to become the new British No. 1 despite losing in qualifying.

Dan Evans is in pole position to become British No. 1 (Picture: Getty)

Evans, who was beaten 2-6 6-4 6-4 by world No. 71 Chardy in the final round of qualifying on Sunday, could be leapfrogged by Cameron Norrie with a deep run in Shanghai, but that seems unlikely given he will next face US Open finalist Daniil Medvedev.

Norrie, who came through qualifying over the weekend, had earlier beaten Chardy’s compatriot Gilles Simon 7-5 6-2 to set up a clash with the world No. 4.

Edmund started well on serve – dropping just one point in his opening two games – but disaster struck in the fifth game of the match when he threw a 40-15 lead to be broken, with Chardy caressing a cross-court forehand winner beyond him to move in front.

It proved to be enough for the Frenchman to take the opening set and while Edmund fought hard in the second, he went down in a tiebreak.

Edmund started the season at world No. 14 but will drop to at least world No. 54. Evans, by contrast, began the season outside the top-190 and is currently the 43rd highest ranked male on the planet.

His climb to the summit of the men’s game in this country is a fine achievement after seeing his ranking vanish entirely less than a year-and-a-half ago after being banned for a year after testing positive for cocaine, and he has applied himself well since returning to the tour.

Cameron Norrie could still become British No. 1 this week (Picture: Getty Images)

Elsewhere, Canadian left-hander Denis Shapovalov booked a tie with world No. 1 Novak Djokovic after beating Frances Tiafoe 6-4 6-2, while Spain’s Albert Ramos Vinolas beat Marin Cilic 6-4 6-4 to set up a meeting with Roger Federer.

Tenth seed Fabio Fognini beat America’s Sam Querrey 6-4 6-2 and could face Andy Murray in the second round.

The British wildcard meets Argentine qualifier Juan Ignacio Londero later on Monday, with Fognini awaiting the winner.
